message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and test results suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is characterized by the presence of blast cells in the peripheral blood and bone marrow. The presence of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and petechial bleeding are all common manifestations of ALL. The mediastinal mass seen on chest radiograph could represent an enlarged thymus or lymphoma, which are both commonly seen in children with ALL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, presence of bruising and petechial bleeding, and the peripheral blood smear showing blasts all suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Aplastic anemia would not explain the leukocytosis and presence of blasts. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia and chronic myeloid leukemia typically occur in older individuals. The presence of a mediastinal mass is also more commonly associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute leukemia, and the presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear confirms it. Hepatosplenomegaly and a mediastinal mass indicated an aggressive form of ALL. Aplastic anemia and CLL do not present with leukocytosis and blasts in the peripheral blood smear. CML usually presents in adults.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and blood tests suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia, which is characterized by leukocytosis, severe anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The presence of blasts in the peripheral smear, as well as the presence of a mediastinal mass, further support this diagnosis. None of the other options present with the same set of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs, as well as the CBC and peripheral blood smear, suggest acute leukemia. The presence of a mediastinal mass on chest radiograph suggests acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The other options are unlikely given the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and test results suggest acute leukemia, and the presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear confirms that it is acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is more common in older adults and its presentation is different from acute leukemia. Aplastic anemia and chronic myeloid leukemia do not have blasts in the peripheral blood smear.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including bruising, bleeding, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, suggest a hematological malignancy. The presence of blasts on the peripheral blood smear indicates acute leukemia. The mediastinal mass seen on chest radiograph suggests T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, such as severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, bruising, and petechial bleeding, are indicative of acute leukemia. The presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear and a mediastinal mass suggests acute lymphoblastic leukemia as the most likely diagnosis. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia usually occurs in the elderly and does not present with blasts. Aplastic anemia would not show leukocytosis, and chronic myeloid leukemia would not present with a mediastinal mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with blasts in the peripheral blood smear suggest acute leukemia. The mediastinal mass and hepatosplenomegaly further suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia typically occurs in older adults and is usually asymptomatic, while aplastic anemia does not involve leukocytosis or blasts in peripheral blood. Chronic myeloid leukemia typically presents with high white blood cell counts but not necessarily anemia or thrombocytopenia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute leukemia, and the peripheral blood smear confirms this with the presence of blasts. The mediastinal mass may be a mediastinal lymph node or thymus. The hepatosplenomegaly is likely due to infiltration by leukemia cells. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is more common in older adults and presents with lymphadenopathy, not mediastinal masses. Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia, not leukocytosis. Chronic myeloid leukemia presents with leukocytosis and splenomegaly but not with lymphadenopathy or mediastinal masses.
